resource.name: numerical_analysis
resource.purpose: This part of ISO 10303 specifies an integated resource for the representation of analysis problems and the solutions of such problems.

inscope.li: idealisations of product definitions evinced by analyses.

definition.def:
representation of one thing by another thing that in a particular context is both simpler than, and an approximation to, the first thing. In the context of a numerical calculation, the numbers 3, 22/7, 355/113, and 3.14159265 are all idealisations of the mathematical constant pi, in increasing order of reality.
In the context of a finite element analysis, a mesh of elements is an idealisation of the shape of the thing being analysed.

schema.name: analysis_product_relationships_schema
schema.introduction: This schema specifies relationships between the definitions of objects and analyses.
schema.fund_cons: The analysis_product_relationships_schema associates the concepts in the product_analysis_schema and analysis_schema with the product structure core specified in ISO 10303-41 providing a specification of the idealisation and analysis of the product.

schema.name: product_analysis_schema
schema.introduction: This schema defines and describes the structures for describing a view of the objects (products, activities and states) that may be the subject of an analysis.
schema.fund_cons:
The product_analysis_schema has two key concepts:
temporal spatial domain: This is a definition of the real world object that is analysed. The properties of this object are a specification of the analysis.
analysis model: This is a model of the real world object that is analytically tractable.
A single temporal spatial domain may have many analysis models defined for it.
Temporal spatial domain The subject of an engineering analysis is a temporal spatial domain that is defined by a set of properties. An analysis model of a temporal spatial domain is derived from these properties.
The set of properties that define a temporal spatial domain may include shape.
Hence a temporal spatial domain is a class. A particular physical individual is a member of the class if it possesses the defining properties. An analysis model of a temporal spatial domain is assumed to be valid for each member of the class.
The properties that define a temporal spatial domain may be obtained by measurements made on a particular physical individual, and may include features such as cracks. Nonetheless, if another physical individual were found with identical properties, the same analysis model would be equally applicable to it.
Because a temporal spatial domain is a class, some properties may have statistical measures, such as mean, variance, and range.
Physical domain A physical domain is a representation of a temporal spatial domain with assumptions about the nature of the temporal spatial domain that allow analysis.

schema.name: analysis_schema
schema.introduction: This schema defines and describes the structures for describing analyses.
schema.fund_cons:
An analysis model may assume that the temporal spatial domain is a continuum, and may also assume an analytically convenient dimension for that continuum.
If an analysis model is a continuum, then there is a 'membership' concept which is interpreted as a place within the continuum. A field is a function from the continuum to a property space. For example a temperature field is a function from the continuum to the property space 'temperature'. There is also a membership concept for a temporal spatial domain. In this case, the members are the physical individuals that have the properties assigned to the temporal spatial domain.
The temporal spatial domain may be a beam during a loading process. Different analysis models may be created as follows:
an analysis model that assumes the beam at each instant to be a 3D continuum of points occupied by matter;
an analysis model that assumes the unloaded beam to be a 1D continuum of plane surfaces occupied by matter, and the loaded beam to be a 1D continuum of surfaces occupied by matter which are not necessarily plane;
an analysis model that assumes the beam at each instant to be a 1D continuum of plane surfaces occupied by matter.
Properties of the temporal spatial domain may also be properties of the analysis model. However, simplified analytically tractable properties may be assumed for an analysis model.
The stress-strain behaviour of a temporal spatial domain may be very complicated. An approximate elastic behaviour may be assumed for analysis.
